Dialogue.NPCText:
A gentle woman kneels before a lacquered shrine, plucking a haunting melody from a four-stringed biwa strung with pale, shimmering hair.

She looks up with wise, kind eyes.

"Ah... a spirit stirs upon the wind. I am Emiko, guardian of the old songs and teller of Hinokami's hidden histories. Have you come seeking music, wisdom, or something that weighs heavier upon your soul?"

Option.text: I hear your music, but sense sorrow. Why do you play?
Can you teach me your spirit-banishing arts?
Tell me of the old stories you guard.
Do you need aid, Priestess?
Tell me more about yourself, Emiko.
Just listening. Farewell.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko plucks a trembling note, the air shimmering faintly.

"Music binds the spirit and the world. My biwa—strung with my own hair—can soothe restless ghosts, or drive out those too stubborn to depart.
Each song preserves a memory. To forget is to lose ourselves to darkness. Even Minax fears what lingers in forgotten verses."

Option.text: Can your music truly banish spirits?
What stories do you guard?
How can I help?
Thank you for your wisdom.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko smiles, setting her biwa across her knees.

"Few outside Hinokami have the patience for such craft. But if your heart is steady, I can show you the Song of Purifying Dawn. It drives evil spirits from hidden places, but only when played with reverence.

Will you listen closely, and vow to use this art only for good?"

Option.text: I vow to use your song to protect the innocent.
What if I misuse your knowledge?
I wish to learn, but not today.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko plucks a complex, uplifting melody—the air brightens, and faint motes swirl around you.

"You learn the Song of Purifying Dawn. Play it when darkness creeps near, and you may banish spirits that haunt shrine and home.

(Your Musicianship skill improves. Some spirits may now respond to your music in future quests!)"

Option.text: Thank you, Emiko.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko’s eyes narrow, sorrowful.

"Song shapes spirit as surely as sword shapes flesh. If you turn this gift to selfishness or cruelty, even Minax’s demons may pale beside what you unleash. All songs have a price."

Option.text: I understand. Please teach me.
Perhaps another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko traces a faded sigil on her biwa’s lacquered body.

"Hinokami’s people fled Minax’s wrath, but our stories survived—carried in music and whispered at night.
Some say the Verdant Tribes’ shamans were once our kin, until the world was torn asunder.
I remember the ballad of Lord British’s last blessing, and the day Minax’s shadow fell over the cherry trees.

Which tale draws you: exile, unity, or the coming darkness?"

Option.text: Tell me of Hinokami’s exile.
What unity do you hope for?
What darkness comes?
Thank you for your stories.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"We crossed the sea under moonlight, bringing what little we could: a branch of cherry, a handful of sacred soil, and our songs.
Minax’s monsters stalked our ships, but spirit-lanterns kept them at bay.
Here, in Hinokami, we planted hope. Yet exile always aches in our hearts."

Option.text: How do you keep hope alive?
Tell me of the coming darkness.
Thank you for your story.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"I dream of a festival where Hinokami and the Verdant Tribes share music beneath blooming trees. But wounds run deep.
Perhaps, with brave hearts, we can heal the land—spirit and song together stronger than steel.
Will you help me bring peace someday?"

Option.text: If the chance arises, I will.
That dream seems distant.
Tell me of the coming darkness.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko sighs. "Perhaps you are right. But every harmony begins with a single note."
She resumes plucking the biwa softly.

Option.text: Thank you, Emiko.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Then I entrust you with hope, as I entrust my biwa to the dawn. Thank you, friend."

Option.text: Farewell, Priestess.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Minax’s sorcery twists the spirits of land and sea. Where music once brought peace, now shadows gather. Ghosts grow bold, and nightmares whisper at every shrine.
But remember: a single song can drive back a thousand shadows—if sung with a pure heart."

Option.text: May your music protect Hinokami.
Can I help you resist the darkness?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko listens, then nods solemnly.

"A spirit of vengeance haunts the riverbank beneath the cherry trees. My music weakens it, but I lack the strength to banish it alone.
If you would aid me, take this Spirit-Binding Charm. Use it when the wailing grows strongest, and return with proof of the spirit’s release.

Will you accept this task?"

Option.text: I accept. Give me the Spirit-Binding Charm.
Is it dangerous?
Not right now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko hands you a woven charm, faintly humming with magic.
"Return when the spirit’s cries are silenced. Bring me a Whispering Fragment as proof, and you will have my thanks—and perhaps a song of power."

Option.text: I will return.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"The spirit was once a protector, corrupted by grief. It lashes out at the living, but fears music and sacred light. Face it with courage, and let your intent be pure.
Take the charm only if your heart is ready."

Option.text: I am ready. Give me the Spirit-Binding Charm.
Not yet.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko lowers her gaze for a moment, fingers resting gently on the strings of her biwa.

"You honor me by asking. Most hear only the music, not the woman behind it. Very well... Would you hear of my youth, my vow, or the strings I bear?"

Option.text: Tell me of your youth.
What vow binds you?
Your biwa... the strings are made of your hair?
Another time, perhaps.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"I was born on the western shores of Tokuno—before Minax razed our temple. My mother was a spirit-singer, my father a gardener who grew trees from prayers.
When the black ships came, we fled under lanternlight, singing songs meant to lull angry ghosts. I was ten. I’ve never stopped singing since."

Option.text: That must have been hard for a child.
Is that when you became a priestess?
And yet you still sing. That is strength.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko nods slowly.
"Hard... but necessary. I learned early that grief can bind a soul tighter than love. But it can also guide us, if we give it rhythm. That’s what the songs are for."

Option.text: How did you become a priestess?
That grief… does it ever ease?
You’ve given me much to think on.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Grief is a ghost that never fully fades. But with each telling—each song—I feel its weight lessen. When I help others do the same… I think even my mother would smile."

Option.text: Tell me about your training.
You are strong, Emiko.
I hope to honor those I’ve lost, as you do.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"After the flight, I trained at the floating monastery of Tsunokai. We chanted to sunrise and plucked storms from the air with string and bone.
I passed the final trial by singing through the night to soothe a weeping spirit that had haunted a bell tower for decades."

Option.text: What happened to the spirit?
That must have required great courage.

Dialogue.NPCText: "When dawn came, she faded into blossoms. Her name was Saya. I carved it into my biwa. Every time I play, I call her spirit to witness. She guides my fingers when I falter."

Option.text: That is beautiful.
Do other spirits guide you too?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko smiles faintly.
"Courage is only the name we give fear once we act despite it. I was terrified. But she was more terrified of being forgotten."

Option.text: Tell me about the spirits you help.
What vow did you take?

Dialogue.NPCText:
She nods solemnly, brushing a strand from her eyes.

"Yes. Each year, I offer a lock of my hair at the Spirit Festival and restring my biwa. The spirits know me by the strand—they recognize the pain, the growth, the intention.
Some say it’s morbid. But spirits are personal things. So my music must be, too."

Option.text: That is... strangely moving.
Option.action: SendMessage:You feel a chill pass through you.

Option.text: Does it hurt to pluck them?
That explains why your music feels alive.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Yes. And no. It hurts more the first time. After that, you learn to braid the pain into the song. Then it becomes a memory, not a wound."

Option.text: You have turned pain into power.
What vow did you swear, Emiko?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Not all spirits are kind—or cruel. Some are lost children. Some are warriors who never stopped fighting. Some are just lonely.
I don’t force them to move on. I help them understand that they can."

Option.text: Have you ever failed?
That takes great patience.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko’s eyes darken slightly.
"Once. A spirit too broken to remember its name. It tore through my melodies and shattered three charms. I still hear it sometimes, wailing across the cliffs. One day, I will return to finish the song."

Option.text: May your voice bring peace to it someday.
What vow did you take?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Emiko lays her hand over her heart.
"My vow is threefold: to sing the forgotten, to soothe the restless, and to never play a false note—even under threat.
Music is truth. And I would rather perish than let Minax silence mine."

Option.text: That is a noble vow. I honor it.
Thank you for trusting me with your story.
May I ask more another time?
